awd_titl_txt: CAREER: From Data to Knowledge and Decisions for Global-Scale Ecological Sustainability
awd_abstract_narration:
Emerging global data resources---for example, from citizen science projects, animal tracking devices, and earth observation instruments---hold exceptional promise for monitoring biodiversity, advancing scientific discovery, and guiding decisions to conserve Earth's natural systems. However, the full potential of these novel data resources has not been realized. The data is heterogeneous, high-dimensional, and spatiotemporal. Planning problems for conservation and sustainable development have huge numbers of states and actions, and significant modeling uncertainty. This career-development project supports an integrated program of research, teaching, and outreach to develop new algorithms to convert data into knowledge and decisions for global-scale ecological sustainability. The methods are expected to help improve scientific understanding of animal populations, increase the value of citizen science data, and contribute to development plans that balance social, economic, and ecological objectives. 

The technical research goals are to develop new models and algorithms for reasoning about large-scale probabilistic models and for network-based spatiotemporal planning. A new class of graphical models based on probability generating functions is proposed to cleanly model animal populations, and to provide a new and flexible class of deep generative models for general multivariate count data. A novel inference approach based on automatic differentiation will be combined with existing inference techniques to support scalable inference and learning. Algorithms that utilize causal reasoning will be developed to tease apart process from noise in citizen science data. Algorithms that exploit hierarchical structure in spatiotemporal domains will be developed to optimize multiple objectives in a highly scalable way to support sustainable development. The education plan will promote diversity, train students to conduct computer science research to solve societally relevant problems, and improve student learning outcomes through a combination of research, instructional, and mentoring activities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project supported the development of new algorithms and software for probabilistic inference, scientific discovery for ecological sustainability and public health, and privacy-preserving data analysis. It also supported an integrated program of education and outreach for the principal investigator.

Emerging data resources hold exceptional promise for scientific discovery. However, in areas like ecology and public health, data are complex, heterogeneous, and don’t directly measure quantities of interest. For example, observations from birdwatchers reveal evidence of bird migration but do not directly record movements. Similarly, disease surveillance data show evidence of disease spread but do not directly measure transmission. Probabilistic inference is an important tool to allow humans to gain insight and make predictions from data. A user combines observed data with a model describing the system to make inferences about unobserved variables. This project developed algorithms and tools for computationally efficient probabilistic inference to support applied scientific inquiry.

One line of research focused on making general-purpose probabilistic inference algorithms faster, more accurate, and more robust. Since this problem is computationally difficult in general, practical approaches rely on approximations. Two broad classes of approximate methods are Monte Carlo methods and variational inference (VI). The project developed new algorithms to make VI more accurate using ideas from Monte Carlo methods. It also developed new algorithms to make VI faster or more robust by improving the stochastic optimization procedures associated with VI. New methods were also created to make Monte Carlo approaches faster by transforming models to support faster inference. Additional results included new models and algorithms for specific problems and for denoising observational data.

A second line of research used probabilistic inference and other AI methods to advance scientific discovery. Two focus areas were bird migration and disease modeling. Significant results included a new model to predict bird migration routes from data collected by birdwatchers, and a model to forecast the spread of COVID-19. The COVID-19 model was found to be the most accurate individual model in a large-scale analysis of models that created weekly forecasts of US COVID-19 deaths in the period from April 2020 to October 2021.

A third line of research focused on methods to protect the privacy of individuals when analyzing data. Privacy is quantified using the differential privacy framework, which provides rigorous mathematical guarantees about disclosure risk. State-of-the-art methods were developed for solving multiple tasks with privacy guarantees, including: (1) the Private-PGM framework, which supports privately answering database queries and generating synthetic datasets and was the basis of a winning entry in a private synthetic data contest run by the National Institute of Standards (NIST), (2) the permute-and-flip mechanism, which solves the task of privately selecting the “best” item more accurately than prior approaches. Other algorithms were developed to improve the efficiency or accuracy of generating private synthetic data and for constructing confidence intervals while maintaining differential privacy.

Overall, the award supported more than 30 scientific publications.

On the educational side, seven graduate students and two undergraduates received direct training as part of the award. The principal investigator adopted research-backed pedagogical practices in his courses including peer instruction, mastery-based grading, and a flipped classroom. The PI also co-created two new programs for computer science undergraduates: a “near-peer" mentoring program to improve retention and academic outcomes for women and underrepresented minorities in computing, and EMBER, a hands-on research experience and seminar with a focus on broadening participation in computer science research.
